Your Majesty asked your minister,
and your minister dared not but answer with the truth."
The king's expression settled,
and then he asked the ministers of other surnames.
He said:
"If the ruler has faults, then admonish him.
If, after repeated admonitions, he does not listen,
then leave."
*Gaozi, Part 1*
11.1 Gaozi said:
"Human nature is like the willow,
and righteousness
is like cups and bowls.
To make benevolence and righteousness out of human nature
is like making cups and bowls out of the willow."
Mencius said:
"Can you follow the nature of the willow
to make cups and bowls?
Or will you injure and harm the willow
and then make cups and bowls?
If you must injure and harm the willow
to make cups and bowls,
then will you also injure and harm people to make benevolence and righteousness?
He who leads the people of the world to bring disaster upon benevolence and righteousness
must be your words!"
11.2 Gaozi said,
"Human nature
is like rushing water.
If you breach it to the east, it flows east;
if you breach it to the west, it flows west.
That human nature has no distinction between good and not good
is like water having no distinction between east and west."
Mencius said,
"Water is indeed without distinction of east and west.
Is it without distinction of up and down?
The goodness of human nature
is like water flowing downwards.
There is no human who is not good;
there is no water that does not flow down.
Now, take water, if you slap it and make it leap,
you can make it go higher than your forehead.
If you force it to flow,
you can make it stay on a mountain.
Is this the nature of water?
It is the force that makes it so.
That humans can be made to do what is not good,
their nature is just like this."
11.3 Gaozi said,
"What is born is called nature."
Mencius said,
"What is born is called nature;
is it like saying white is called white?"
Gaozi said,
"Yes."
"The whiteness of a white feather,
is like the whiteness of white snow;
the whiteness of white snow
is like the whiteness of white jade, is it not?"
He said:
"Yes."
"In that case, the nature of a dog
is like the nature of an ox,
and the nature of an ox
is like the nature of a man, is it not?"
11.4 Gaozi said:
"Appetite for food and sexual desire
are nature.
Benevolence
is internal,
it is not external;
righteousness
is external,
it is not internal."
Mencius said:
"How can you say that benevolence is internal and righteousness is external?"
He said:
"He is elder and I treat him as elder,
it is not because I have elderliness within myself;
it is like something being white and I acknowledge its whiteness,
I follow its whiteness from the outside,
therefore I say it is external."
He said:
"Being different from 'white' is like the 'white' of a white horse,
it is no different from the 'white' of a white person.
Not knowing the 'length' of a long horse,
is it no different from the 'length' of a tall person?
Moreover, does one mean the long one,
or the one that causes something to be long?"
He said:
"I love my younger brother,
but I do not love the younger brother of a Qin person.
It is because I am the one who takes pleasure in it,
therefore it is called 'internal'.
Regarding the 'length' of a tall Chu person,
it is also like the 'length' of my tall one,
it is because 'length' is what pleases me,
therefore it is called 'external'."
He said:
"Enjoying the roasted meat of a Qin person,
is no different from enjoying my roasted meat.
Things being so, then that is how it is.
In that case, is enjoying roasted meat also something 'external'?"
11.5 Meng Jizi asked Gongduzi, saying:
"What is meant by 'righteousness is internal'?"
He said:
"Acting upon my reverence,
therefore it is called 'internal'."
"If a villager is one year older than my elder brother,
whom should I revere?"
Someone asked:
"Revere elder brother."
"In pouring wine, whom should one pour for first?"
Someone replied:
"Pour for the villagers first."
"The reverence is here [with the elder brother],
the seniority is there [with the villagers].
The effect comes from the outside,
not from within."
Gongdu Zi could not answer,
and told Mencius about it.
Mencius said:
"Do you revere your uncle,
or do you revere your younger brother?
He will probably say:
'Revere my uncle.'
Suppose one asks:
'If the younger brother is acting as the impersonator of the deceased,
whom do you revere?'
He will probably say:
'Revere the younger brother.'
You can then ask:
'Where is the reverence for the uncle in that case?'
He will probably say:
'It is because of his position.'
You can also say:
"It is because of their positions."
"Respectful demeanor is shown towards elder brothers;
momentary respect is shown towards fellow villagers."
Ji Zi heard this and said,
"Respect towards uncles is respect,
respect towards younger brothers is respect;
truly, it originates externally,
not from within."
Gongdu Zi said,
"In winter, one drinks hot broth;
in summer, one drinks water.
Then, does drinking also originate externally?"
11.6 Gongdu Zi said,
"Gaozi said,
'Human nature is neither good nor not good.'"
"Some say,
'Human nature can be made good,
and can be made not good;
therefore, when Wen and Wu arose,
the people loved goodness;
when You and Li arose,
the people loved violence.'"
"Some say,
'There are those whose nature is good,
and there are those whose nature is not good;
therefore, with Yao as ruler, there was Xiang;
with Gusou as father, there was Shun;
with Zhou as nephew
Furthermore, if you consider them as rulers,
then there were men like Wei Zi Qi and Prince Bi Gan."
Now you say "human nature is good,"
then were they all wrong?"
Mencius said,
"Concerning their inherent tendencies,
then they could become good,
and that is what is meant by good.
As for their doing what is not good,
that is not the fault of their inherent capacity.
The heart of commiseration,
everyone has it;
the heart of shame and dislike,
everyone has it;
the heart of reverence and respect,
everyone has it;
the heart of right and wrong,
everyone has it.
The heart of commiseration is
benevolence;
the heart of shame and dislike is
righteousness;
the heart of reverence and respect is
propriety;
the heart of right and wrong is
wisdom.
Benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom
are not forged into me from the outside,
It is something I inherently possess,
I simply do not think about it.
Therefore it is said:
‘Seek it and you will obtain it,
abandon it and you will lose it.’
Those whose potential is multiplied many times without measure,
are those who cannot fully realize their talents.
The *Book of Poetry* says:
‘Heaven gives birth to the multitude of people,
for every thing there is a rule.
The people hold onto constancy,
and cherish this beautiful virtue.’
Confucius said:
‘The author of this poem,
truly understands the Dao!
Therefore for every thing there is a rule;
the people hold onto constancy,
therefore they cherish this beautiful virtue.’"
11.7 Mencius said:
“In prosperous years,
young men are mostly easy-going;
in lean years,
young men are mostly violent.
It is not that Heaven sends down different talents,
but rather the way they are led to corrupt their hearts.
Now, consider the barley and wheat,
sow the seeds and cover them,
the soil is the same,
The time of planting is the same,
and they spring forth abundantly,
until the time the sun arrives,
they are all ripe.
Although there are differences,
it is because the land has fertile and barren patches,
the nourishment of rain and dew,
and the unevenness of human effort.
Therefore, all those of the same kind
are generally similar.
Why doubt this only when it comes to people?
Sages and I are of the same kind.
Therefore, Longzi said:
"If one does not know the size of the foot to make shoes,
I know that he will not make a basket."
The similarity of shoes
is because the feet of the world are the same.
With regard to taste,
mouths have a common preference;
Yi Ya was the first to understand what my mouth preferred.
If the nature of the mouth with regard to taste
were different from others,
like dogs and horses are different from us,
then why would
everyone's preferences follow Yi Ya's understanding of taste?
Regarding taste,
the world relies on Yi Ya,
which shows that the mouths of the world are similar.
The same is true for the ear.
As for sounds,
the world esteems Shi Kuang,
meaning that the ears of the world are similar.
The same is true for the eye.
As for Zi Du,
the world universally knows of his beauty.
Those who do not know of Zi Du's beauty
are those who have no eyes.
Therefore it is said:
"As for the mouth and flavors,
there are common preferences;
as for the ear and sounds,
there are common hearings;
as for the eye and colors,
there are common appreciations of beauty."
As for the heart,
is there truly nothing it shares?
What is it that hearts share?
What is it?
It refers to principle and
righteousness.
Sages are the first to grasp
what our hearts share.
Therefore, the pleasure principle and righteousness give our hearts
is like the pleasure that fine meat gives our mouths."
11.8 Mencius said:
"The trees of Niu Mountain were once beautiful,
Because it is near a great state,
axes and hatchets fell it.
Can it then be beautiful?
This is where it rests day and night,
where rain and dew moisten it.
It's not that sprouts and shoots do not grow there.
But cattle and sheep also follow and graze on it.
Therefore, it looks like that bald appearance.
People see its bald appearance
and think it never had timber.
How can this be the nature of the mountain?
Even those existing in humans,
how can they not have hearts of benevolence and righteousness?
That by which they let go of their good heart
is also like axes and hatchets to trees,
to fell it day after day.
Can it then be beautiful?
Where they rest day and night,
the morning's breath,
that which is close to others in their likes and dislikes is very little.
Then what they do during the day
imprisons and destroys it.
The imprisonment's repetition
causes the evening breath to be insufficient to preserve it.
If the evening breath is insufficient to preserve it,
then its distance from birds and beasts is not far.
People see its beastliness
and think it never had talent.
Is this truly the way of human nature?
Therefore, if they obtain proper nourishment,
there is nothing that will not grow;
if they lose proper nourishment,
there is nothing that will not wither.
Confucius said:
'Hold it, and it will remain;
release it, and it will be lost;
its coming and going are without fixed time,
no one knows its dwelling place.'
Is he not speaking of the mind?"
11.9 Mencius said:
"There is no wonder that the king is not wise.
Even with the easiest things in the world to grow,
if you expose them to the sun for one day
and freeze them for ten days,
there has never been anything that could grow.
I have seen him too infrequently.
When I withdraw,
those who freeze him come near.
What can I do if I have a budding idea?
Now, taking playing chess as a skill,
it is a small skill;
if you do not concentrate your mind and focus your will,
you will not succeed.
Yi Qiu
was the best chess player in the whole country.
Suppose Yi Qiu were to teach two people to play chess,
One of them concentrated his attention,
listening only to Yi Qiu.
The other, though listening,
was thinking with all his heart that a swan goose was about to arrive,
wanting to take up his bow and arrow to shoot it.
Though he was learning together with the other,
he was not as good as him.
Is it because his wisdom was not as good?
I say:
"It is not so."
11.10 Mencius said:
"Fish
is what I desire,
bear's paw
is also what I desire;
if I cannot have both,
I will give up the fish and take the bear's paw.
Life
is also what I desire,
righteousness
is also what I desire;
if I cannot have both,
I will give up life and take righteousness.
Life is also what I desire,
but there are things I desire more than life,
therefore I will not seek to obtain it through improper means.
Death is also what I hate,
but there are things I hate more than death,
Therefore, there are calamities that people do not avoid.
If what people desire is nothing more than life,
then everything that can obtain life,
what would they not use?
If what people hate is nothing more than death,
then everything that can avoid calamity,
what would they not do?
From this,
life exists, yet there are things they will not use to obtain it;
from this, it is possible to avoid calamity,
yet there are things they will not do to avoid it.
Therefore, there are desires that exceed life,
and there are things hated more than death.
It is not only the virtuous who possess this mindset;
everyone has it,
but the virtuous are able to not lose it.
A basket of rice,
a bowl of soup,
if obtained, one lives;
if not obtained, one dies.
To offer it with a shout,
a passerby will not accept it;
to offer it with a kick,
even a beggar will disdain it.
But ten thousand *zhong* of grain, they will accept it without discerning whether it is in accordance with propriety and righteousness.
What does ten thousand *zhong* add to me?
Is it for the beauty of palaces and houses,
the service of wives and concubines,
Would those poor and destitute people you know receive it from me?
Formerly, you would not accept it to avoid death;
now, you accept it for the beauty of palaces and mansions.
Formerly, you would not accept it to avoid death;
now, you accept it for the sake of pampering your wives and concubines.
Formerly, you would not accept it to avoid death;
now, you accept it so that those poor and destitute people you know will receive it from you.
Isn't this also something that cannot be stopped?
This is what is called losing one's original heart."
11.11 Mencius said:
"Benevolence
is the heart of man;
righteousness
is the path of man.
To abandon one's path
and not follow it,
to let go of one's heart
and not know to seek it back,
is lamentable!
If someone's chickens or dogs run away,
they know to seek them back;
but they let go of their heart
and do not know to seek it back.
The way of learning and inquiry is nothing other than
seeking back one's lost heart."
11.12 Mencius said:
"Now, if someone's ring finger
is bent and cannot be straightened,
It is not that illness and pain hinder affairs.
If there were someone who could trust in this,
then they would not consider the road to Qin and Chu to be far,
because they realize their pointing abilities are not as good as others.
If their pointing abilities are not as good as others,
then they know to dislike that;
if their hearts are not as good as others,
then they do not know to dislike that.
This is what is called not knowing the category."
11.13 Mencius said:
"A handful of *tong* and *zi* saplings,
if people truly want to grow them,
they all know how to nourish them.
As for their own bodies,
they do not know how to nourish them.
Is it that they love their bodies less than *tong* and *zi* trees?
It is simply a lack of thought."
11.14 Mencius said:
"Regarding the body,
people love it comprehensively.
If they love it comprehensively,
then they should nourish it comprehensively.
If there is no inch of skin that they do not love,
then there should be no inch of skin that they do not nourish.
The means by which one examines whether it is good or bad,
is there any other way?
It is simply to take it from oneself.
The body has what is noble and base,
There are the small and the great.
Do not let the small harm the great,
do not let the base harm the noble.
Nourishing what is small makes one a small man;
nourishing what is great makes one a great man.
Now, there is a field manager
who abandons his tung and catalpa trees,
and cultivates his jujube trees and thorn bushes.
He is then a base field manager.
If one nourishes one finger
and loses his shoulders and back,
yet does not know it,
then he is a wolf-disease afflicted man.
People who only care about eating and drinking
are looked down upon,
because they nourish the small
and lose the great.
If people who only care about eating and drinking
do not lose the great,
then would the mouth and belly
be only for a mere inch of skin?"
11.15 Gongduzi asked,
"All are men,
yet some become great men
and some become small men.
Why is this?"
Mencius said,
"Those who follow their greater part
To act as a great man,
follow one's greater part;
to act as a small man, follow one's lesser part."
Someone asked:
"Both are human beings,
some follow their greater part,
and some follow their lesser part.
Why is this?"
Mencius said:
"The offices of the ears and eyes do not think,
and are obscured by things.
When things interact with things,
they are merely led by them.
The office of the heart thinks.
Thinking results in obtaining;
not thinking results in not obtaining.
This is what Heaven has given us.
First establish oneself in the greater part,
then the lesser part cannot steal it away.
This is simply to act as a great man."
11.16 Mencius said:
"There are heavenly ranks,
and there are human ranks.
Benevolence, righteousness,
loyalty, trustworthiness,
delight in goodness without weariness;
these are heavenly ranks.
Dukes, ministers, and great officers;
This is a human title.
The people of old
cultivated their heavenly titles,
and human titles followed.
The people of today
cultivate their heavenly titles in order to seek human titles;
having obtained human titles, they abandon their heavenly titles.
This is the greatest delusion,
and in the end, they will surely perish."
11.17 Mencius said,
"The desire for nobility
is a common feeling among people.
Everyone has nobility within themselves,
but they simply do not think about it.
The nobility conferred by others
is not true nobility.
What Zhao Meng values,
Zhao Meng can also demean.
The *Book of Poetry* says,
'Already drunk with wine,
already sated with virtue.'
This speaks of being sated with benevolence and righteousness,
and therefore not desiring the rich flavors of delicacies;
having a good reputation and widespread praise bestowed upon oneself,
and therefore not desiring the embroidered finery of others."
11.18 Mencius said,
"Benevolence overcoming unbenevolence
is like water overcoming fire.
Those who practice benevolence today
are like using a cup of water to extinguish a cartload of burning firewood.
If it doesn't extinguish the fire,
they say the water cannot overcome the fire.
This is even more unbenevolent.
In the end, they will surely perish."
11.19 Mencius said,
"The five grains
are the best of seeds.
If they fail to ripen,
they are not as good as weeds.
Benevolence also lies in ripening it."
11.20 Mencius said,
"When Yi taught people archery,
he surely focused on drawing the bow to its fullest extent.
Learners must also focus on drawing the bow to its fullest extent.
A master craftsman teaching people
surely uses compass and square;
learners must also use compass and square."
*Gaozi II*
12.1 Ren Ren asked Wu Lu Zi,
"Which is more important, ritual or food?"
He said,
"Ritual is more important."
"Which is more important, sex or ritual?"
He said,
"Ritual is more important."
Someone said:
"If one eats according to ritual, then one will starve to death;
if one does not eat according to ritual, then one will obtain food,
must one necessarily follow ritual?
If one personally welcomes the bride, then one will not obtain a wife;
if one does not personally welcome the bride, then one will obtain a wife,
must one necessarily personally welcome the bride?"
Wu-lu Tzu was unable to answer,
and the next day went to Zou
to tell Mencius.
Mencius said:
"What difficulty is there in answering this?
Not examining the foundation,
but making the extremities equal,
a square inch of wood can be made higher than a tall storied building.
That gold is heavier than feathers,
how can it be said to mean a single hook of gold
compared with a cartload of feathers?
Taking the heavier matter of food
and comparing it with the lighter matter of ritual,
how can one say food is not heavier?
Taking the heavier matter of sex
and comparing it with the lighter matter of ritual,
how can one say sex is not heavier?
Go and answer him, saying:
'If one twists one's elder brother's arm and steals food from him,
then one will obtain food;
If you do not twist it,
then you will not get food.
Then will you twist it?
Climbing over the eastern neighbor's wall and embracing his maiden,
then you will get a wife;
if you do not embrace her,
then you will not get a wife.
Then will you embrace her?” 」
12.2 Cao Jiao asked, saying:
"Everyone can become a Yao or Shun,
is that true?"
Mencius said:
"Yes."
"[I] Jiao have heard that King Wen was ten feet tall,
and Tang was nine feet tall.
Now Jiao is nine feet four inches tall,
and eats millet.
How then can I do it?"
[Mencius] said:
"What difficulty is there in this?
Just do it.
If there is a person here
whose strength is not enough to lift a chick,
then he is a weak person.
If he now lifts a hundred jun,
then he is a strong person.
If he then lifts the weight of Wu Huo,
then he is Wu Huo.
Surely, one should not be concerned with a lack of ability to succeed,
but rather with simply not doing it.
To walk slowly behind an elder
is called being a good younger brother;
to walk quickly ahead of an elder
is called not being a good younger brother.
Now, walking slowly,
is it something that people are incapable of doing?
It is something they simply do not do.
The Way of Yao and Shun
is nothing more than filial piety and fraternal respect.
If you wear the clothes of Yao,
recite the words of Yao,
and perform the actions of Yao,
then you are simply Yao.
If you wear the clothes of Jie,
recite the words of Jie,
and perform the actions of Jie,
then you are simply Jie."
Someone said:
"If I could secure an audience with the ruler of Zou,
I could obtain lodging.
I wish to stay and receive instruction at your door."
Mencius said:
"The Way is like a great road,
how can it be difficult to know?
People's problem is simply that they do not seek it.
If you return home and seek it,
have more teachers."
12.3 Gongsun Chou asked,
"Gaozi said,
the "Little Ospreys"
is a poem of petty men."
Mencius said,
"On what basis do you say this?"
He said,
"It expresses resentment."
Mencius said,
"How narrow-minded indeed
is old Gao's understanding of poetry!
If there were a man here,
and a man from Yue drew his bow and shot at him,
he would laugh and talk about it.
There is no other reason
than that he is estranged from him.
If his elder brother drew his bow and shot at him,
he would weep and cry as he spoke of it.
There is no other reason
than that he is close to him.
The resentment in "Little Ospreys"
is about being close to one's relatives.
Being close to one's relatives
is benevolence.
How narrow-minded indeed
is old Gao's understanding of poetry!"
Gongsun Chou said,
"Why does the 'Kai Feng' not complain?"
He said:
"'Kai Feng' speaks of [parents whose] affection is too little;
"'Kai Feng' is about parents whose affection is too little;
'Xiao Bian' is about [parents whose] affection is too great.
'Xiao Bian' is about parents whose affection is too great.
Not resenting parents whose affection is too great,
is becoming increasingly estranged.
Resenting parents whose affection is too little,
is being impossible to get along with.
Becoming increasingly estranged
is unfilial;
being impossible to get along with
is also unfilial.
Confucius said:
'Shun was truly the utmost filial son,
at fifty he still yearned [for his parents' affection].'"
12.4 Song Keng was going to Chu.
Mencius met him at Shi Qiu,
and said:
"Where are you going, Master?"
He said:
"I heard that Qin and Chu are preparing for war,
and I intend to see the King of Chu
to persuade him to stop it.
If the King of Chu is displeased,
I intend to see the King of Qin
to persuade him to stop it.
"I will be meeting with the two kings."
He said:
"Ke, please do not ask for the details,
I wish to hear your intention.
How will you persuade them?"
He said:
"I will speak of their disadvantage."
He said:
"Sir, your ambition is great,
but your approach is unacceptable.
If you persuade the kings of Qin and Chu with profit,
and the kings of Qin and Chu are pleased with profit
and disband the armies of the three forces,
then the soldiers of the three forces will gladly disband
and be pleased with profit.
If a subject
serves his ruler with thoughts of profit,
if a son
serves his father with thoughts of profit,
if a younger brother
serves his elder brother with thoughts of profit,
then ruler and subject,
father and son, brothers will ultimately abandon benevolence and righteousness,
and interact with each other with thoughts of profit,
yet not perish,
such a thing has never happened.
If you persuade the kings of Qin and Chu with benevolence and righteousness,
and the kings of Qin and Chu are pleased with benevolence and righteousness
To stop the army of the three legions,
it is because the soldiers of the three legions are happy to be dismissed
and are pleased with benevolence and righteousness.
If a person serving as a minister
cherishes benevolence and righteousness to serve his ruler,
if a person serving as a son
cherishes benevolence and righteousness to serve his father,
if a person serving as a younger brother
cherishes benevolence and righteousness to serve his elder brother,
it means that ruler and subject,
father and son,
brothers abandon profit,
cherish benevolence and righteousness to interact with each other,
yet not become king,
such a case has never occurred.
Why must you speak of profit?"
12.5 Mencius was residing in Zou,
and Ji Ren was the magistrate of Ren.
He offered gifts in exchange for friendship,
and Mencius accepted them but did not reciprocate.
When residing in Pinglu,
Chu Zi was the prime minister.
He offered gifts in exchange for friendship,
and Mencius accepted them but did not reciprocate.
Another day, while traveling from Zou to Ren,
he met with Ji Zi;
while traveling from Pinglu to Qi,
he did not meet with Chu Zi.
Wu Lu Zi rejoiced and said,
"I have finally found an opening!"
He asked,
"When you took office, you met with Ji Zi;
when you went to Qi, you did not meet with Chu Zi.
Was it because of their positions as ministers?"
Mencius replied,
"No.
The *Book of Documents* says,
'When the sacrificial offerings are many and proper,
but the rites do not match the offerings,
it is considered not a true sacrifice;
it is solely because one does not devote one's mind to the sacrifice.'
It was because it was not a complete sacrifice."
Wu Lu Zi was pleased.
Someone asked him about it.
Wu Lu Zi said,
"Ji Zi was not to be found in Zou,
but Chu Zi was to be found in Pinglu."
12.6 Chun Yu Kun said,
"Those who put reputation and reality first
are for the sake of others;
those who put reputation and reality last
are for the sake of themselves.
You, sir, were among the three highest ministers,
but before your reputation and reality were enhanced
either above or below, you left.
Is this how a benevolent person acts?"
Mencius said:
"To remain in a low position and not serve the unworthy with one's virtue is Bo Yi's way.
and not serve the unworthy with one's virtue is the way of Bo Yi;
to serve Tang five times
To approach Tang five times
and approach Jie five times is Yi Yin's way.
To not despise a defiled ruler
and not decline a small office is Liu Xiahui's way.
These three men followed different paths,
but their goal was the same.
What was this single goal?
I say:
It was benevolence.
The superior man is also simply benevolent.
Why must they be the same?"
Someone said:
"During the time of Duke Mu of Lu,
Gongyi Zi was in government,
and Ziliu and Zisi were ministers,

Mencius said,
"A great craftsman does not alter or discard his plumb line and compass for the sake of a clumsy workman,
and Yi did not change his draw length for the sake of a poor archer.
The gentleman draws the bow but does not release the arrow,
making a leaping posture.
Standing in the middle way,
the capable follow it.”
13.42 Mencius said:
“When the Way prevails in the world,
one sacrifices oneself to the Way.
When the Way does not prevail in the world,
one sacrifices one's life for the Way.
I have never heard of anyone sacrificing the Way for the sake of another person."
13.43 Gongdu Zi said:
"When Teng Geng was at your gate,
he seemed to be observing the proper etiquette,
but you did not answer him.
Why is that?"
Mencius said:
"To ask questions relying on one's nobility,
to ask questions relying on one's virtue,
to ask questions relying on one's seniority,
to ask questions relying on one's meritorious service,
to ask questions relying on one's past acquaintance—
these are all reasons for not answering.
Teng Geng possessed two of these."
13.44 Mencius said:
"When one stops doing something that is impossible to stop,
there is nothing that one will not stop doing.
When one treats those whom one should value with indifference,
there is nothing that one will not treat with indifference.
Those who advance rapidly
will retreat quickly."
13.45 Mencius said,
"The gentleman's attitude towards things
is to cherish them but not to be benevolent towards them;
towards the people,
he is benevolent towards them but not intimate with them.
Be intimate with relatives and then be benevolent towards the people;
be benevolent towards the people and then cherish things."
13.46 Mencius said,
"The wise man is not ignorant of anything,
but considers the most pressing matters to be urgent;
the benevolent man loves everything,
but considers urgently befriending the worthy to be the priority.
Yao and Shun's wisdom did not encompass all things,
because they prioritized the most pressing matters;
Yao and Shun's benevolence
did not extend to loving everyone equally,
because they prioritized befriending the worthy.
To be unable to observe the three-year mourning period
while scrutinizing the *zī* and *xiǎogōng* garments;
to eat gluttonously and drink sloppily
while questioning whether food has been cut properly—
this is called not knowing what is important."
*Jinxin* (Exhausting the Mind), Part 2
14.1 Mencius said,
"How unbenevolent
King Hui of Liang is!
The benevolent man
Those who are benevolent use what they love, as well as what they do not love.
Those who are not benevolent
use what they do not love, as well as what they love."
Gongsun Chou asked,
"What does this mean?"
"King Hui of Liang, because of territory,
destroyed his people and fought.
He was greatly defeated,
and intended to recover it,
but feared he would not be able to win,
therefore he drove his beloved sons and younger brothers to die for it.
This is what is called
using what he does not love, as well as what he loves."
14.2 Mencius said:
"In the Spring and Autumn period, there were no righteous wars.
One might be better than another,
but that's all.
A punitive expedition
is when a superior attacks an inferior;
enemy states do not punish each other."
14.3 Mencius said:
"To completely believe the *Book of Documents*
is worse than having no *Book of Documents*.
From the *Wu Cheng* chapter,
I only take two or three passages.
A benevolent person has no enemies in the world.
When the utmost benevolence attacks the utmost lack of benevolence,
How could the blood have flowed enough to float pestles?"
14.4 Mencius said:
"Someone said:
'I am good at arranging battle formations,
I am good at fighting.'
This is a great crime.
If the ruler of a state loves benevolence,
he will have no enemies in the world.
If he faces south to attack, the northern barbarians will resent it;
if he faces east to attack, the western barbarians will resent it,
saying:
'Why did he put me last?'
When King Wu attacked Yin,
he had three hundred chariots and
three thousand brave warriors.
The king said:
'Do not fear!
I am here to bring you peace,
not to make enemies of the common people.'
They collapsed, hitting their heads on the ground.
The meaning of 'attack' is 'to rectify,'
everyone wants to rectify themselves,
so what need is there for war?"
14.5 Mencius said:
"Carpenters, joiners, wheelwrights, and cartwrights
can give people compasses and squares,
but they cannot make people skilled."
14.6 Mencius said:
"When Shun ate dried provisions and ate grasses,
it was as if he would do so for his entire life.
But when he became the Son of Heaven,
he wore embroidered garments,
played the lute,
and had two daughters
in attendance, as if he had always possessed them."
14.7 Mencius said,
"Only now do I understand
the gravity of killing someone's relatives:
if you kill someone's father,
someone will also kill your father;
if you kill someone's brother,
someone will also kill your brother.
Therefore, it is not really killing oneself;
there is only a slight interval."
14.8 Mencius said,
"In ancient times, the purpose of establishing passes
was to defend against violence;
nowadays, the purpose of establishing passes
is to commit violence."
14.9 Mencius said,
"If one does not practice the Way oneself,
one cannot influence one's wife and children;
if one employs people without the Way,
one cannot influence one's wife and children."
14.10 Mencius said,
"One who is thorough in seeking profit
"A year of famine cannot kill;
one who is complete in virtue
cannot be thrown into chaos by a corrupt world."
14.11 Mencius said:
"A person who loves fame
can yield a state of a thousand chariots;
but if it is not the right person,
a simple meal of rice and bean soup will show on their face."
14.12 Mencius said:
"If one does not trust in benevolence and worthiness,
then the state will be empty;
without propriety and righteousness,
then superiors and inferiors will be in chaos;
without good governance,
then material resources will be insufficient."
14.13 Mencius said:
"There have been those who obtained a state without benevolence;
this has happened;
but there has never been anyone who obtained the world without benevolence."
14.14 Mencius said:
"The people are the most important,
the altars of soil and grain come next,
and the ruler is the least important.
Therefore, one who gains the support of the common people becomes the Son of Heaven;
one who gains the support of the Son of Heaven becomes a feudal lord;
one who gains the support of the feudal lords becomes a grand officer.
If a feudal lord endangers the altars of soil and grain,
then change and replace them.
When the sacrificial animals are prepared,
the millet offerings are purified,
and sacrifices are offered on time,
yet there are still droughts and floods,
then change and replace the altars of the soil and grain."
14.15 Mencius said,
"Sages
are teachers for a hundred generations.
Bo Yi and Liu Xiahui are examples.
Therefore, those who hear of Bo Yi's influence
make greedy men honest,
and those who are weak-willed become resolute.
Those who hear of Liu Xiahui's influence
make those who are unkind, sincere,
and those who are petty-minded, generous.
They rise up above hundreds of generations,
and those who hear of them hundreds of generations later cannot but rise up.
Could anyone other than a sage be capable of this?
How much more so those who have directly been influenced by them?"
14.16 Mencius said,
"Ren (benevolence)
is what it means to be human.
When combined and spoken of together,
it is the Dao (the Way)."
14.17 Mencius said,
"When Confucius left Lu,
he said,
『"I linger on the way,"
is the way to leave one's parents' state.'
Leaving Qi,
he cooked the rice in haste and departed,
is the way to leave another state."』
14.18 Mencius said,
"The superior man in distress between Chen and Cai
had no communication with those above or below."
14.19 Mo Ji said,
"I, Ji, am very poor at speaking."
Mencius said,
"It does not matter.
Scholars dislike this much speaking.
The Book of Poetry says,
'My heart is full of sorrow,
and I am angry with all the small men.'
That refers to Confucius.
'He did not entirely suppress his anger,
nor did he diminish his fame.'
That refers to King Wen."
14.20 Mencius said,
"The wise man uses his clear understanding
to enlighten others,
but now people use their clouded understanding
to enlighten others."
14.21 Mencius said to Gao Zi,
"The path in the mountains, with short
intervals of use, becomes a road;
When one does not use his mind for contemplation,
it becomes overgrown with weeds.
Now, the weeds are overgrowing your mind."
14.22 Gaozi said,
"The music of Yu
surpassed the music of King Wen."
Mencius said,
"How do you say this?"
He said,
"Based on the sound of the bell pendants."
Mencius said,
"Is that sufficient reason?
The ruts in the city gate
are made by the force of two horses?"
14.23 There was famine in Qi.
Chen Zhen said,
"The people of the state all think that you, Master,
will again distribute grain at Tang,
but that is probably no longer possible."
Mencius said,
"That would be like Feng Fu.
There was a man of Jin named Feng Fu,
who was good at wrestling tigers,
but he eventually became a virtuous scholar.
Once, he went to the countryside
and there was a crowd chasing a tiger.
The tiger, relying on the hill,
no one dared to approach it.
Seeing Feng Fu,
they hurried to welcome him.
Feng Fu bared his arm and alighted from the carriage.
The crowd was pleased with this,
but those who were scholars laughed at him."
14.24 Mencius said:
"The mouth's relation to flavors,
the eye's relation to colors,
the ear's relation to sounds,
the nose's relation to odors,
and the four limbs' relation to ease and comfort,
these are matters of nature.
There is destiny involved in them,
but the gentleman does not call them nature.
Benevolence's relation to father and son,
righteousness's relation to ruler and minister,
propriety's relation to guest and host,
wisdom's relation to the worthy,
and the sage's relation to the Way of Heaven,
these are matters of destiny.
There is nature involved in them,
but the gentleman does not call them destiny."
14.25 Hao Sheng Bu Hai asked,
"What kind of man
is Yue Zhengzi?"
Mencius said,
"He is a good man,
a trustworthy man."
"What is good?
What is trustworthy?"
He said:
"That which is desirable is called good,
that which exists within oneself is called trustworthy,
that which is full and substantial is called beautiful,
that which is full and substantial and has radiance is called great,
that which is great and transforming is called sage,
that which is sage and unknowable is called divine."
"As for Yue Zhengzi,
he is in the middle of the second rank,
and at the bottom of the fourth rank."
14.26 Mencius said:
"Those who flee Mo will certainly return to Yang,
those who flee Yang will certainly return to Confucianism.
Once they return,
simply accept them.
Those who debate with the Yangists and Moists today
are like chasing a runaway pig,
which has already entered its pen,
yet they still try to beckon it back."
14.27 Mencius said:
"There are taxes in cloth and silk,
taxes in grain and rice,
and taxes in labor service.
The ruler should use one of these
and ease the other two.
If he uses two
And the people starve to death,
even though [only] a third of their resources are used,
and fathers and sons are separated."
14.28 Mencius said,
"The treasures of a feudal lord are three:
land, people, and governance.
Those who treasure pearls and jade,
disaster will certainly befall them."
14.29 Peng Cheng Kuo served as an official in Qi.
Mencius said,
"Peng Cheng Kuo is doomed!"
Peng Cheng Kuo was killed.
A disciple asked,
"How did the Master know he would be killed?"
He said,
"As a person,
he has some small talent,
but has not heard of the great Way of the gentleman.
Therefore, that is enough to get him killed."
14.30 When Mencius went to Teng,
he was lodged at the Shang Palace.
There were sandals placed above the window,
and the innkeeper sought them but could not find them.
Someone asked him,
"Is this how lax your followers are?"
He said,
"Do you think someone came here to steal sandals?"
The person said,
"That is probably not right."
"Now, in my setting up of these divisions [of learning],
what has passed is not pursued,
what comes is not refused.
If one arrives with this sincerity,
then he is accepted, that is all."
14.31 Mencius said:
"All men have something they cannot bear.
Extending that to what they *can* bear is
benevolence.
All men have something they will not do.
Extending that to what they *will* do is
righteousness.
If a man can fully develop his heart of not desiring to harm others,
then benevolence cannot be exhausted in its application.
If a man can fully develop his heart of not boring through and climbing over (walls),
then righteousness cannot be exhausted in its application.
If a man can fully develop his heart of not receiving the substance of 'you' and 'thou' (i.e., disrespect),
then there is nowhere he will go where he will not practice righteousness.
For a scholar to speak when it is not permissible to speak
is to use speech to ingratiate himself.
To not speak when it is permissible to speak
is to use silence to ingratiate himself.
These are all akin to boring through and climbing over (walls)."
14.32 Mencius said:
"Words that are simple yet point to what is far-reaching
are good words.
Holding to the essential yet bestowing broadly
(This is) the good way.
The words of a gentleman
need not descend to trivialities
yet the Way is present within them.
In the preservation of a gentleman,
he cultivates his own person,
and the world becomes peaceful.
People are troubled by abandoning their own fields
to cultivate the fields of others.
What they seek from others is great,
but what they rely on themselves for is little."
14.33 Mencius said:
"Yao and Shun
were so by nature;
Tang and Wu
reverted to it.
Moving in demeanor and acting with decorum,
is the culmination of great virtue.
Grieving over the dead
is not for the sake of the living.
Upholding virtue without deviation
is not for the sake of seeking office.
Words must be trustworthy,
not for the sake of correcting behavior.
A gentleman acts according to the law,
and simply awaits destiny."
14.34 Mencius said:
"When persuading great men,
then scorn them;
do not look at their imposing grandeur.
If the hall is several fathoms high,
and the beams and rafters are several feet thick,
if I were to achieve my ambition, I would not do that.
If the food spread before me covered a square foot,
and I had hundreds of serving girls,
if I were to achieve my ambition, I would not do that.
If I engaged in excessive music and drinking,
drove around hunting,
with a thousand chariots following behind,
if I were to achieve my ambition, I would not do that.
Those things that are over there,
are all things I would not do;
the things that are with me,
are all the institutions of antiquity,
why should I fear them?"
14.35 Mencius said:
"Nothing is better for nourishing the heart than having few desires.
If a person has few desires,
even if some of their original goodness is lost,
it will be little;
if a person has many desires,
even if some of their original goodness remains,
it will be little."
14.36 Zeng Xi liked jujubes,
but Zengzi could not bear to eat jujubes.
Gongsun Chou asked,
"Which is better, sliced roasted meat or jujubes?"
Mencius said,
"Sliced roasted meat, of course!"
Gongsun Chou said,
"Then why did Zengzi eat sliced roasted meat
but not jujubes?"
Mencius said,
"Sliced roasted meat is something enjoyed by all;
jujubes are something only enjoyed by some.
One avoids the name of someone, but not the surname.
The surname is something enjoyed by all;
the name is something unique."
14.37 Wan Zhang asked,
"When Confucius was in Chen,
he said,
'Why not return!
The young men of my district are ambitious and independent,
eager to advance,
and do not forget their origins.'
When Confucius was in Chen,
why did he think of the 'mad' scholars of Lu?"
Mencius said,
"Confucius said,
'Since I cannot find those who pursue the Mean to associate with,
I must then associate with the 'mad' or 'prudish'!
The 'mad' are eager to advance,
and the 'prudish' have things they will not do.'
Did Confucius not desire the Mean?
"If something cannot certainly be obtained,
then one considers the next best thing."
He asked, "May I ask what kind of person can be called '狂' (kuáng, wild/ambitious/unconventional)?"
The Master said,
"People like Qin Zhang, Zeng Xi, and Mu Pi
are what Confucius called '狂.'"
"Why are they called '狂'?"
The Master said,
"Their ambitions are lofty and boastful,
saying,
'The ancients,
the ancients!'
Yet examining their conduct,
they do not conceal their flaws.
If one cannot obtain a '狂,'
and desires to find those who are not fastidious or pure to associate with,
that is '獧' (juàn, cautious/compromising),
which is again a lesser thing.
Confucius said,
'Those who pass by my door without entering my room,
whom I do not regret,
are perhaps the village worthies!
Village worthies
are the thieves of virtue!'"
He asked,
"What kind of person can be called a 'village worthy'?"
The Master said,
"Why is he so boastful?
If speech does not consider action,
and action does not consider speech,
then people will say,
"The ancients, the ancients."
Why act so lonely and desolate?
Being born into this world,
living for this world,
being good is enough.
Those who obsequiously flatter the world,
are village worthies."
Wan Zi said,
"An entire village calls someone a 'worthy person,'
and wherever they go, they are treated as a 'worthy person.'
Confucius considered them a thief of virtue,
why is that?"
Mencius said,
"There is nothing to criticize in them,
nothing to point out in them,
they conform to the vulgar customs,
and fit in with the defiled world.
Their behavior seems loyal and trustworthy,
their actions seem honest and pure,
and everyone is pleased with them.
They consider themselves right,
but they cannot be brought into the way of Yao and Shun,
therefore it is said,
'A thief of virtue.' Confucius said,
'I hate those who are similar but not the same:
One dislikes the weeds,
fearing they will disorder the seedlings;
one dislikes the flatterers,
fearing they will disorder righteousness;
one dislikes clever talkers,
fearing they will disorder trustworthiness;
one dislikes the music of Zheng,
fearing it will disorder proper music;
one dislikes purple,
fearing it will disorder vermilion;
one dislikes the village worthies,
fearing they will disorder virtue."
The superior man returns to the classics, that is all.
When the classics are correct,
then the common people rise (are aroused);
when the common people rise,
then there will be no evil or wickedness."
14.38 Mencius said,
"From Yao and Shun to Tang,
it was more than five hundred years;
as for Yu and
Gao Yao, they saw and knew it;
as for Tang, he heard and knew it.
From Tang to King Wen,
it was more than five hundred years;
as for Yi Yin and Lai Zhu, they saw and knew it;
as for King Wen, he heard and knew it.
From King Wen to Confucius,
More than five hundred years [have passed].
If it were Taigong Wang or San Yisheng,
they would know by seeing;
if it were Confucius, he would know by hearing.
From the time of Confucius until now,
more than a hundred years [have passed].
The distance from the age of the Sage
is not so far,
the proximity to the Sage's residence
is so very close,
and yet there is nothing to be gained here,
then there is nothing to be gained here.
